awd_titl_txt: Thinking Globally, Acting Locally: Increasing CS Capacity and Equity by Developing a Regional CS Teacher Community
awd_abstract_narration:
Siena College proposes to leverage and expand an existing researcher-practitioner partnership (RPP) to create a new community-focused professional development (PD) model for preparing high quality computer science (CS) teachers capable of increasing the number and diversity of students in their schools' CS classrooms. Siena College's past work and strong ties to secondary CS and mathematics education in New York State's Tech Valley region are ideal for developing a regional CS teacher community and for addressing, in a significant manner, the problem of underrepresented groups in CS. 

The work has five key components: 
(1)	Community Based PD for In-Service Teachers: A new PD program will prepare in-service math/technology teachers to teach Siena's introductory college level dual-enrollment CS course or a high school level CS course. It will integrate teachers, counselors, administrators and college faculty into a sustainable CS professional learning community via the dual-enrollment program, annual CS outreach events for teachers and their students, and collaboration with the local Computer Science Teachers Association (CSTA) chapter.
(2)	Diversity Initiative: Drawing on expertise in the RPP, high school teachers will be assisted in developing and implementing plans for increasing the number and diversity of students in their CS classrooms, customizing their plans based on the unique conditions, opportunities and challenges at their high schools.
(3)	In-Service Teacher Second Certification in CS: Pathways will be created for in-service teachers to earn up to fourteen college CS credits over the two year grant period. These credits can count towards New York State's recently approved second certification in CS.
(4)	Pre-Service Teacher Initial Certification in CS: A new program for CS initial certification for undergraduates will be established, making it one of the first in New York State. As a tool for recruiting current undergraduates into the program, Siena students will have opportunities to serve as assistants for CS teachers in the RPP. 
(5)	Community Building Programming: The Siena College CS Department will continue to support and expand its outreach activities which include programs for high school students and sponsorship of the Upstate New York CSTA chapter meetings.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: Computer Science for All (CS for All)

por.por_cntn:
In this project, a team of Siena College computer science (CS) and education faculty developed and implemented a new model for improving secondary CS education through comprehensive college/high school partnerships.  The model increased CS teacher capacity and broadened student participation in foundational CS high school classes in 30 school districts in upstate New York. 

To address the shortage of CS teachers, the grant principal investigators (PIs) provided curriculums and professional development (PD) to over 37 high school teachers certified in other areas so that they could confidently offer two foundational CS courses at their high schools.  The curriculums included a new full year high school level Discovering CS course developed as part of the grant and a college level dual-enrollment Introduction to CS with Python and Multimedia course.  During the COVID pandemic, both curriculums were adapted for online learning to support the schools’ move to remote instruction.   The PD consisted of a summer kick-off workshop and regular school year PD meetings.  It covered CS content knowledge, pedagogy, and research-based equitable teaching practices for engaging diverse student groups.  Teachers also developed and implemented school-based plans for increasing the number and diversity of students enrolled in their CS classrooms, with a focus on groups historically underrepresented in CS including female, Black and Latinx students.  

As part of this grant work, Siena College became the first college/university to offer a NYS Education Department (NYSED) approved pre-service teacher initial CS certification program.  To support in-service teachers certified in other areas, the grant PIs offered Siena College CS classes in the late afternoons with remote options so that the teachers could enroll in them.  This deepened their CS content knowledge and may count towards an additional teaching certificate in CS through NYSED’s individual evaluation pathway.  During the grant period, 23 teachers completed a combined total of 127 CS college credits.      

Access to and participation in high school CS classes increased significantly as a result of building this CS teacher capacity. Because rural and high-needs districts are less likely to offer CS to their students, we intentionally recruited such districts into our partnership.  16 of the 30 districts involved in the grant were rural and 9 were high-needs.  In the last year of the grant (AY2022-23), 721 high school students took the Siena supported Discovering CS or the dual-enrollment Introduction to CS with Python and Multimedia course, and 386 of these students were at high-needs schools. That is up nearly tenfold from the 77 high school students that took a Siena supported CS course in the year prior to the start of the grant (AY2018-19), and none of these students were attending a high-needs school.

The PD, shared CS curriculums, and college course taking provided a foundation for a rich professional learning community (PLC) of high school and college educators. This PLC was further supported through college sponsored outreach and engagement activities that included an annual high school programming contest, hosting meetings of the local chapter of the CS Teacher Association on Siena’s campus, and college visit days for students in Siena supported high school CS classes.

While implementing the comprehensive college/high school partnership model, the grant PIs and high school partners collected and analyzed data to evaluate its effectiveness. This data included CS student surveys, CS student interviews, CS teacher surveys, and CS teacher focus groups.  The results indicated that the model is effective in producing confident CS teachers that have a strong sense of belonging to a CS professional learning community.  Survey analysis also indicated that the CS classes are contributing to reducing pre-course gender gaps in students' perceived efficacy and belonging in CS classrooms. The surveys also pointed to females being more engaged in the CS classes and developing stronger relationships with their CS teachers than their male peers. The PIs disseminated these results through academic research presentations and publications and also at math and CS teacher/educator conferences with our high school partners.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 04/07/2023
Modified by: Robin Y Flatland
por.por_txt_cntn:
In this project, a team of Siena College computer science (CS) and education faculty developed and implemented a new model for improving secondary CS education through comprehensive college/high school partnerships.  The model increased CS teacher capacity and broadened student participation in foundational CS high school classes in 30 school districts in upstate New York. 

To address the shortage of CS teachers, the grant principal investigators (PIs) provided curriculums and professional development (PD) to over 37 high school teachers certified in other areas so that they could confidently offer two foundational CS courses at their high schools.  The curriculums included a new full year high school level Discovering CS course developed as part of the grant and a college level dual-enrollment Introduction to CS with Python and Multimedia course.  During the COVID pandemic, both curriculums were adapted for online learning to support the schools’ move to remote instruction.   The PD consisted of a summer kick-off workshop and regular school year PD meetings.  It covered CS content knowledge, pedagogy, and research-based equitable teaching practices for engaging diverse student groups.  Teachers also developed and implemented school-based plans for increasing the number and diversity of students enrolled in their CS classrooms, with a focus on groups historically underrepresented in CS including female, Black and Latinx students.  

As part of this grant work, Siena College became the first college/university to offer a NYS Education Department (NYSED) approved pre-service teacher initial CS certification program.  To support in-service teachers certified in other areas, the grant PIs offered Siena College CS classes in the late afternoons with remote options so that the teachers could enroll in them.  This deepened their CS content knowledge and may count towards an additional teaching certificate in CS through NYSED’s individual evaluation pathway.  During the grant period, 23 teachers completed a combined total of 127 CS college credits.      

Access to and participation in high school CS classes increased significantly as a result of building this CS teacher capacity. Because rural and high-needs districts are less likely to offer CS to their students, we intentionally recruited such districts into our partnership.  16 of the 30 districts involved in the grant were rural and 9 were high-needs.  In the last year of the grant (AY2022-23), 721 high school students took the Siena supported Discovering CS or the dual-enrollment Introduction to CS with Python and Multimedia course, and 386 of these students were at high-needs schools. That is up nearly tenfold from the 77 high school students that took a Siena supported CS course in the year prior to the start of the grant (AY2018-19), and none of these students were attending a high-needs school.

The PD, shared CS curriculums, and college course taking provided a foundation for a rich professional learning community (PLC) of high school and college educators. While implementing the comprehensive college/high school partnership model, the grant PIs and high school partners collected and analyzed data to evaluate its effectiveness. This data included CS student surveys, CS student interviews, CS teacher surveys, and CS teacher focus groups.  The results indicated that the model is effective in producing confident CS teachers that have a strong sense of belonging to a CS professional learning community.  Survey analysis also indicated that the CS classes are contributing to reducing pre-course gender gaps in students' perceived efficacy and belonging in CS classrooms. The surveys also pointed to females being more engaged in the CS classes and developing stronger relationships with their CS teachers than their male peers. The PIs disseminated these results through academic research presentations and publications and also at math and CS teacher/educator conferences with our high school partners.
